raw_response: {"answer_index": 0, "answer_text": "Psoriatic arthritis", "confidence": 9, "reasoning": "This patient presents with classic features of psoriatic arthritis: (1) asymmetric oligoarthritis affecting knees at different times, (2) inflammatory back pain that improves with rest, (3) nail pitting - a key dermatologic finding, and (4) dandruff (likely scalp psoriasis). The combination of joint symptoms, axial involvement, and psoriatic skin/nail changes strongly points to psoriatic arthritis. Arthritis mutilans is a severe destructive form of psoriatic arthritis, not a separate diagnosis. Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with symmetric small joint involvement and lacks nail changes. Mixed connective tissue disease would have other systemic features.", "evidence_quality": "normal"}
